greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Lower triangle T(j,k) read by rows, where T(j,k) is the number of occurrences of the digit k-1 as least significant digit in the base-j multiplication table.
comment: Assumes a suitable continuation of the representation of digits in bases 11, 12 (9,A,B,..)
example: a(2)=T(2,1)=3 because 3 of the 4 possible combinations of last digits in the
product of two binary numbers produce 0 as last digit of the result. a(3)=T(2,2)=1 because only ...1 * ...1 gives a result with last digit=1.
T(10,k)={27,4,12,4,12,9,12,4,12,4} gives the probability in percent (j^2=100) to get {0,1,2,...,9} as last decimal digit in the decimal representation of the product of two arbitrary integers.
results.author: _Hugo Pfoertner_, Jun 02 2004
